item.title: When Vietnam and China Bicker, Traders on the Border Feel the Bluster
item.description: Political ups and downs between Hanoi and Beijing have profound effects on the small-scale traders who live near the shared 800-mile boundary.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.media:credit: Aaron Joel Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Vietnamese trader pushed a cart loaded with goods across the border to Lao Cai, Vietnam, from Hekou, China.

item.title: ISIS Carries Out Deadly Attacks on Syrian Border Town of Kobani
item.description: Twelve people were killed and 70 were wounded in a car bombing and other attacks by the militants, hospital officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: As they waited at the border to cross into Turkey on Thursday, relatives of a woman who died after being wounded in Kobani, in northern Syria, mourned over her body.

item.title: ISIS Attacks Two Border Towns in Northern Syria
item.description: Islamic State militants set off car bombs in Kobani, where they had been driven out before by Kurdish guerrillas, and attacked the government-held city of Hasaka.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAHER SAMAAN
item.media:description: As they waited at the border to cross into Turkey on Thursday, relatives of a woman who died after being wounded in Kobani, in northern Syria, mourned over her body.

item.title: High-Ranking Official From Burundi Says He Fled Country Over Safety Fears
item.description: Gervais Rufyikiri is the third top government figure to leave the African country since unrest was stirred when the president announced a bid for a third term.
item.dc:creator: SADI NIYUNGEKO and ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Gervais Rufyikiri, Burundi’s second vice president.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Opens New Land Route to Tibet for Indian Pilgrims
item.description: The crossing on Monday of Nathu La signaled the official opening of a new pilgrimage route for Indians to the holy sites of Mount Kailash and Lake Manasarovar.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Two 8-year-old American girls on the Kailash pilgrimage trail with Indian tourists in orange jackets.

item.title: Myanmar’s Military Uses Political Force to Block Constitutional Changes
item.description: The military, which controls a quarter of the seats, voted against a bill rescinding its veto power and refused to ease a rule that helps prevent the opposition leader from becoming president.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Military representatives voted on constitutional amendments at the Parliament in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, on Thursday.

item.title: With Beijing’s Voting Plan Dead, Hong Kong Looks for Way Forward
item.description: A week after rejection of a proposal that would have let the public elect the top leader, the second-guessing, maneuvering and recriminations have begun.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pro-democracy campaigners holding yellow umbrellas during a march against the Beijing-backed election plan before its defeat in the Hong Kong legislature.

item.title: Death Toll From Heat Wave in Pakistani Port of Karachi Hits 1,000
item.description: Searing temperatures, which have been as high as 113 degrees, were below 100 on Thursday, but a sense of panic and crisis persisted in the city.
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ and ZIA ur-REHMAN
item.media:description: Cooling off in a puddle in Karachi, Pakistan, on Thursday, as the death toll from a heat wave reached 1,000.

item.title: Taxi Drivers Protest Uber in Clashes Across France
item.description: The anger is the latest in a series of challenges facing the service, which has been accused of breaking laws and creating unfair competition.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Taxi drivers protesting Uber blocked access to Orly Airport, south of Paris.

item.title: Foreign Donors Pledge $3 Billion to Help Rebuild Quake-Ravaged Nepal
item.description: The country’s government on Thursday sought to assure would-be contributors that the funds would be used effectively.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: China Aims to Move Beijing Government Out of City’s Crowded Core
item.description: The move is a recognition, urban planners and historians say, that the existing strategy has created ever-worsening traffic problems, and widespread destruction of Beijing’s monumental old city.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: For more than 65 years, Chinese government officials worked and lived near the Forbidden City, creating traffic problems and widespread destruction in Beijing’s old city.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fined for Having Baby, Unwed Couple Ask Chinese Public to Pitch In
item.description: Shen Bolun and Wu Xia, who are not married, celebrated the smooth delivery of a healthy girl in Beijing on Sunday, but it came at a price: A government fine of about $7,200.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER and ADAM WU
item.media:description: A family visiting Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 1 to celebrate Children’s Day.

item.title: Bulgaria Fears Fallout From Greece’s Financial Troubles
item.description: Nobody knows what destructive forces could be unleashed if Greece fails to resolve its crisis, and Bulgaria — home to several Greek-owned banks — has much to lose.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Widespread Graft Expanded After Tunisian Revolt, Study Says
item.description: The World Bank revealed that companies owned by the family of the former Tunisian president defrauded the state of $1 billion to $2.6 billion.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali in 2010, the year before he was deposed. The World Bank has issued a new study on corruption in Tunisia.

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Captive’s Family Tries New Appeal
item.description: Relatives of Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran imprisoned in Iran for nearly four years are traveling to Vienna, where talks are being held about Iran’s nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N.’s Yemen Mediator Depicts Grim Scene of Deprivation
item.description: The mediator said polio could soon make a comeback in Yemen, people are ‘one step away from famine,’ and that a humanitarian truce remained elusive.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Bosnia-Herzegovina: Court Grants Compensation to War Crimes Victim
item.description: The former soldiers were sentenced to 10 years in prison and ordered to pay $15,160 to a Croat woman they raped during the Serb attack on her village in 1992.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Obama Bolsters His Leverage With Trade Victory, but at a Cost
item.description: In rescuing his trade legislation, the president worked with Republicans but may have worsened relations with fellow Democrats.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: World Briefing: Romania: From Frying Pan to Legal Fire
item.description: An ally of Prime Minister Victor Ponta was charged with being an accomplice to embezzling European Union funds and illegally offering incentives to voters.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ruling Says Netherlands Must Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions
item.description: The decision by the Dutch court could motivate environmental activists to pursue a similar legal strategy in other countries.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ
